edition.title: The Birth of Merlin, or, The Child Hath Found his Father

persaliases.persname: Edwin and Cador, Earl of Cornwall
Edwin and Cador, Earl of Cornwall

scene.scenelocation: A room in the castle of Lord Donobert.

stagedir.dir: Enter Lord Donobert, Earl of Gloucester, Cador, Earl of Cornwall, Edwin, Constantia, and Modesta.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: You teach me language, sir, as one that knows the debt of love I owe unto their virtues, wherein, like a true courtier, I have fed myself with hope of fair success, and now attend your wished consent to my long suit.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Believe me, youthful lord, time could not give an opportunity more fitting your desires, always provided my daughter’s love be suited with my grant.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: ’Tis the condition, sir, her promise sealed.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Is’t so, Constantia?

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: I was content to give him words for oaths, he swore so oft he loved me.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: That thou believest him?

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: He is a man, I hope.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: That’s in the trial, girl.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: However, I am a woman, sir.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: The law’s on thy side, then, sha’t have a husband,— ay, and a worthy one. Take her, brave Cornwall, and make our happiness great as our wishes.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Sir, I thank you.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Double the fortunes of the day, my lord, and crown my wishes too. I have a son here, who, in my absence, would protest no less unto your other daughter.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Ha, Gloster! Is it so? What says lord Edwin? Will she protest as much to thee?

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Else must she want some of her sister’s faith, sir.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Of her credulity much rather, sir. My lord, you are a soldier, and methinks the height of that profession should diminish all heat of love’s desires, being so late employed in blood and ruin.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: The more my conscience ties me to repair the world’s losses in a new successlon.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Necesslty, it seems, ties your affections then, and at that rate I would unwillingly be thrust upon you; a wife is a dish soon cloys, sir.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Weak and diseased appetites it may.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Most of your making have dull stomachs, sir.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: If that be all, girl, thou shalt quicken him: be kind to him Modestia; noble Edwin, let it suffice, what’s mine in her, speaks yours;
For her consent, let your fair suit go on,
She is a woman, sir, and will be won.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: You give me comfort, sir.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Now Toclio.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: The king, my honored lords, requires your presence, and calls a council for return of answer unto the parling enemy, whose ambassadors are on the way to court.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: So suddenly! Chester it seems has plied them hard at war, they sue so fast for peace, which, by my advice, they ne’er shall have, unless they leave the realm. Come, noble Gloster, let’s attend the king; it lies, sir, in your son to do me pleasure, and save the charges of a wedding-dinner.
If you’ll make haste to end your love affairs,
One cost may give discharge to both my cares.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Donobert and Earl of Gloucester.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: I’ll do my best.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Now, Toclio, what stirring news at court?

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: Oh, my lord, the court’s all filled with rumor, the city with news, and the country with wonder; and all the bells i’th’ kingdom must proclaim it; we have a new holiday a-coming.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: A holiday! For whom? For thee?

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: Me, madam! ’s foot, I’d be loth that any man should make a holy-day for me yet. In brief ’tis thus: there’s here arrived at court, sent by the earl of Chester to the king, a man of rare esteem for holiness, a reverend hermit, that by miracle not only saved our army, but without aid of man overthrew the pagan host, and with such wonder, sir, as might confirm a kingdom to his faith.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: This is strange news indeed! Where is he?

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: In conference with the king, that much respects him.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Trust me, I long to see him.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: Faith, you will find no great pleasure in him for aught that I can see, lady; they say he is half a prophet too; would he could tell me any news of the lost prince; there’s twenty talents offered to him that finds him.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Such news was breeding in the morning.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: And now it has birth and life sir; if fortune bless me, I’ll once more search those woods where then we lost him. I know not yet what fate may follow me.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Fortune go with you, sir. Come, fair mistress. Your sister and lord Edwin are in game, and all their wits at stake to win the set.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: My sister has the hand yet, we had best leave them.
She will be out anon as well as I,
He wants but cunning to put in a die.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: You are a cunning gamester, madam.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: It is a desperate game, indeed, this marriage, where there’s no winning without loss to either.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Why, what but your perfection, noble lady, can bar the worthiness of this my suit? If so you please I count my happiness from difficult obtaining, you shall see my duty and observance.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: There shall be place to neither, noble sir. I do beseech you let this mild reply give answer to your suit, for here I vow, if ever I change my virgin name, by you it gains or loses.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: My wishes have their own.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Let them confine you then, as to my promise you give faith and credence.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: In your command my willing absence speaks it.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Noble and virtuous; could I dream of marriage, I should affect thee, Edwin. Oh my soul, here’s something tells me that these best of creatures, these models of the world, weak man and woman, should have their souls, their making, life and being, to some more excellent use. If what the sense calls pleasure were our ends, we might justly blame great nature’s wisdom, who reared a building of so much art and beauty to entertain a guest so far uncertain, so imperfect. If only speech distinguish us from beasts, who know no inequality of birth or place, but still to fly from goodness—oh, how base were life at such a rate! No, no! That power that gave to man his being, speech, and wisdom, gave it for thankfulness. To him alone
That made me thus, may I whence truly know,
I’ll pay to him, not man, the love I owe.

stagedir.dir: Flourish of Cornets. Enter Aurelius, King of Britain; Lord Donobert, Earl of Gloucester, Cador, Earl of Cornwall, Edwin, Toclio, Oswald, and Attendants.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: No tidings of our brother yet? ’Tis strange, so near the court, and in our own land too, and yet no news of him! Oh, this loss tempers the sweetness of our happy conquests, with much untimely sorrow.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Royal sir, his safety being unquestioned, should to time leave the redress of sorrow; were he dead, or taken by the foe, our fatal loss had wanted no quick herald to disclose it.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: That hope alone sustains me, nor will we be so ungrateful unto heaven to question what we fear with what we enjoy. Is answer of our message yet returned from that religious man, the holy hermit, sent by the earl of Chester to confirm us in that miraculous act? For ’t was no less, our army being in rout, nay, quite o’erthrown, as Chester writes; even then this holy man armed with his cross and staff, went smiling on, and boldly fronts the foe; at sight of whom the Saxons stood amazed; for to their seeming, above the hermit’s head appeared such brightness, such clear and glorious beams, as if our men marched all in fire, wherewith the pagans fled, and by our troops were all to death pursued.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: ’Tis full of wonder, sir.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Oh, Gloster, he’s a jewel worth a kingdom. Where’s Oswold with his answer?

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: ’Tis here, my royal lord.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: In writing! Will he not sit with us?

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: His orisons performed, he bade me say he would attend with all submisslon.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Proceed to council then, and let some give order, the ambassadors being come, to take our answer they have admittance. Oswold, Toclio, be it your charge.
And now, my lords, observe the holy counsel of this reverend hermit.
“ As you respect your safety, limit not that only power that hath protected you; trust not an open enemy too far;
He’s yet a loser; and knows you have won;
Mischiefs not ended, are then but begun.
ANSELME, the Hermit.–

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Powerful and pithy, which my advice confirms; no man leaves physic when his sickness slacks, but doubles the receipts; the word of peace seems fair to bloodshot eyes; but being applied with such a medicine as blinds all the sight, argues desire of cure, but not knowledge of art.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: You argue from defects: if both the name and the condition of the peace be one, it is to be preferred; and in the offer made by the Saxon, I see nought repugnant.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: The time of rruce required for,—thirty days—carries suspicion in it, since half that space will serve to strength their weakened regiments.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Who, in less time, will undertake to free our country from them.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Leave that unto our fortune.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Is not our bold and hopeful general still master of the field—their legions fallen, the rest entrenched for fear, half starved, and wounded—and shall we now give o’er our fair advantage? ’Fore heaven, my lord, the danger is far more in trusting to their words than to their weapons.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: The ambassadors are come, sir.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Conduct them in: we are resolved, my lords, since policy failed in the beginning, it shall have no hand in the conclusion. That heavenly power that hath so well begun their fatal overthrow I know can end it; from which fair hope myself will give them answer.

stagedir.dir: Flourish of cornets. Enter Artesia with the Saxon Lords.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: What’s here?—a woman orator?

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Peace, Donobert. Speak, what are you, lady?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: The sister of the Saxon general, warlike Ostorius, the East Angles king; my name Artesia; who, in terms of love, brings peace and health to great Aurelius, wishing the army may return as fair a present as she makes tender of.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: The fairest presence e’er mine eyes were blest with! Command a chair, there, for this Saxon beauty! Sit, lady, we’ll confer: your warlike brother sues for a peace, you say?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: With endless love unto your state and person.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Ha’s sent a moving orator, believe me: what think’st thou, Donobert?

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Believe me, sir, were I but young again, this gilded pill might take my stomach quickly.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: True, thou art old: how soon we do forget our own defects. Fair damsel,—oh, my tongue turns traitor, and will betray my heart,—sister to our enemy:—’s death, her beauty mazes me; I cannot speak if I but look on her.
What’s that we did conclude?

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: This royal lord—

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Pish, thou canst not utter it. Fairest of creatures, tell the king, your brother, that we in love—ha!—and honor to our country, command his armies to depart our realm; but if you please, fair soul—Lord Donobert, deliver you our pleasure.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: I shall, sir: lady, return, and certify your brother—

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Thou art too blunt, and rude: return so soon! Fie! Let her stay; and send some messenger to certify our pleasure.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: What means your grace?

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: To give her time of rest to her long journey: we would not willingly be thought uncivil.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Great king of Britain, let it not seem strange to embrace the princely offers of a friend,
Whose virtues, with thine own, in fairest merit;
Both states in peace and love may now inherit.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: She speaks of love again; sure ’tis my fear, she knows I do not hate her.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Be then thyself, most great Aurelius; and let not envy, nor a deeper sin, in these thy counselors, deprive thy goodness of that fair honor, we, in seeking peace, give first to thee, who never used to sue but force our wishes; yet if this seem light, oh let my sex, though worthless your respect, take the report of thy humanity,
Whose mild and virtuous life loud fame displays,
As being o’ercome by one so worthy praise.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: She has an angel’s tongue! Speak still.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: This flattery is gross, sir; hear no more on’t. Lady, these childish compliments are needless: you have your answer; and believe it, madam, his grace, though young, doth wear within his breast too grave a counselor to be seduced by smoothing flattery, or oily words.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: I come not, sir, to woo him.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: ’T were folly if you should; you must not wed him: shame take thy tongue.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Shame take thy tongue; being old and weak thyself, thou dotest; and, looking on thy own defects, speak’st what thou’dst wish in me: do I command the deeds of others, mine own act not free?
Be pleased to smile or frown, we respect neither;
My will and rule shall stand and fall together.

Most fair Artesia, see, the king descends to give thee welcome with these warlike Saxons, and now on equal terms both sues and grants. Instead of truce, let a perpetual league seal our united bloods in holy marriage: send the East Angles king this happy news—that thou with me hast made a league for ever, and added to his state a friend and brother: speak, dearest love; dare you confirm this title?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: I were no woman to deny so high and noble a proposal to my fame and country.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Live, then, a queen in Britain.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: He means to marry her.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Death! He shall marry the devil first! Marry a pagan—an idolater!

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: He has won her quickly.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: She was wooed afore she came, sure; or came of purpose to conclude the match.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Who dares oppose our will? My lord of Gloster, be you ambassador unto our brother, the brother of our queen, Artesia; tell him, for such our entertainment looks him, our marriage adding to the happiness
Of our intended joys, man’s good or ill,
In this like waves agree—come double still.
Who’s this? The hermit? Welcome my happiness, our country’s hope: most reverend, holy man, I wanted but thy blessing to make perfect the infinite sum of my felicity.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Alack, sweet prince; that happiness is yonder:
Felicity and thou, art far asunder.
This world can never give it.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Thou art deceived: see here what I have found—beauty, alliance, peace, and strength of friends; all in this all-exceeding excellence: the league’s confirmed.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: With whom, dear lord?

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: With the great brother of this beauteous woman, the royal Saxon king.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Oh! Then I see, and fear thou art too near thy misery. What magic could so link thee to this mischief? By all the good that thou hast reaped by me, stand further from destruction.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Speak as a man, and I shall hope to obey thee.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Idolaters, get hence! Fond king, let go!
Thou hug’st thy ruin, and thy country’s woe.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Well spoke, old father, to him; bait him soundly.
Now, by heaven’s blest lady, I can scarce keep patience.

speech.speaker: 1. SAX. LORD.
speech.line: What devil is this?

speech.speaker: 2. SAX. LORD.
speech.line: That cursed Christian, by whose hellish charms our army was o’erthrown.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Why do you dally, sir? Oh! Tempt not heaven; warm not a serpent in your naked bosom; discharge them from your court.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Thou speak’st like madness. Command the frozen shepherd to the shade when he sits warm i’ the sun—the fever-sick to add more heat unto his burning pain—these may obey: ’tis less extremity than thou enjoin’st to me: cast but thine eye upon this beauty; do it; I’ll forgive thee, though jealousy in others finds no pardon; then say thou dost not love me: I shall then swear thou art immortal, and no earthly man: Oh, blame then my mortality, not me.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: It is thy weakness brings thy misery, unhappy prince.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Be milder in thy doom.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: ’Tis you that must endure heaven’s doom, which fallen remember’s just.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Thou shalt not live to see it: how fares my lord? If my poor presence breeds dislike, great prince, I am no such neglected soul, will seek to tie you to your word.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: My word, dear love! May my religion, crown, state, and kingdom fail when I fail thee. Command earl Chester to break up the camp, without disturbance to our Saxon friends; send every hour swift posts to hasten on the king, her brother, to conclude this league, this endless happy peace of love and marriage; till when provide for revels; and give charge that nought be wanting which make our triumphs
Sportful and free to all: if such fair blood
Engender ill, man must not look for good.

stagedir.dir: Flourish. Exit all but the Hermit.
Enter Modesta, reading in a book.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: How much the oft report of this blest hermit hath won on my desires: I must behold him: and sure this should be he. Oh, the world’s folly! Proud earth and dust, how low a price bears goodness! All that should make man absolute shines in him. Much reverent sir, may I, without offense, give interruption to your holy thoughts?

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: What would you, lady?

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: That which till now ne’er found a language in me: I am in love.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: In love! With what?

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: With vertue.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: There’s no blame in that.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Nay, sir, with you! With your religious life. Your virtue, goodness, if there be a name to express affection greater,—that, that would I learn and utter. Reverent sir, if there be anything to bar my suit, be charitable and expose it: your prayers are the same orisons which I will number. Holy sir, keep not instruction back from willingness: possess me of that knowledge which leads you on
To this humility; for well I know
Were greatness good, you would not live so low.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Are you a virgin?

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Yes, sir!

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Your name?

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Modestia.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Your name and virtues meet, a modest virgin: live ever in the sanctimonious way to heaven and happiness. There’s goodness in you—I must instruct you further. Come, look up: behold yon firmament! There sits a power whose footstool is this earth: oh learn this lesson—
And practice it: he that will climb so high,
Must let no joy beneath to move his eye.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: I apprehend you, sir: on heaven I fix my love:
Earth gives us grief; our joys are all above.
For this was man in innocence naked born,
To show us wealth hinders our sweet return.

stagedir.dir: Enter Clown, and Joan his Sister, great with child.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Away, follow me no further, I am none of thy brother; what, with child! Great with child! And know not who’s the father on’t! I am ashamed to call thee sister.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Believe me, brother, he was a gentleman.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Nay, I believe that; he gives arms and legs too, and has made you the herald to blaze ’em; but Joan, Joan, sister Joan, can you tell me his name that did it? How shall we call my cousin, your bastard, when we have it?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Alas! I know not the gentleman’s name, brother; I met him in these woods the last great hunting; he was so kind, and proffered me so much, as I had not the heart to ask him more.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Not his name, why this shows your country breeding now; had you been brought up i’th’ city, you’d have got a father first, and the child afterwards: hast thou no markes to know him by?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: He had most rich attire, a fair Hat and feather, a gilt sword, and most excellent hangers.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Pox on his hangers! Would he had been gelt for his labor.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Had you but heard him swear, you would have thought—

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ay, as you did, swearing and lying goes together still; did his oaths get you with child? We shall have a roaring boy then i’faith. Well, sister, I must leave you.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Dear brother, stay, help me to find him out; I’ll ask no further.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: ’Sfoot, who should I find? Who should I ask for?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Alas! I know not: he uses in these woods, and these are witness of his oaths and promise.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: We are like to have a hot suit on’t, when our best witness’s but a knight o’th’ post.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Do but enquire this forest; I’ll go with you, some happy fate may guide us till we meet him.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Meet him! And what name shall we have for him when we meet him? ’Sfoot, thou neither know’st him, nor canst tell what to call him; was ever man tied with such a business, to have a sister got with child, and know not who did it? Well, you shall see him, I’ll do my best for you, I’ll make proclamation, if these woods and trees, as you say, will bear any witness, let them answer. Oh, yes. If there be any man that wants a name, will come in for conscience’ sake, and acknowledge himself to be a whore-master, he shall have that laid to his charge in an hour, he shall not be rid on in an age; if he have lands he shall have an heir, if he have patience he shall have a wife, if he have neither lands nor patience, he shall have a whore. So ho, boy! So ho, so, so!

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: So ho, boy! So ho, illo ho, illo ho!

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Hark, hark, sister; there’s one holloas to us; what a wicked world’s this; a man cannot so soon name a whore but a knave comes presently, and see where he is; stand close awhile, sister.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: How like a voice that echo spoke! But ah,
My thoughts are lost for ever in amazement;
Could I but meet a man to tell her beauties,
These trees would bend their tops to kiss the air,
That from my lips should give her praises up.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: He talks of a woman, sister.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: This may be he, brother.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: View him well; you see he has a fair sword, but his hangers are fallen.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Here did I see her first, here view her beauty;
Oh had I known her name, I had been happy.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Sister, this is he, sure; he knows not thy name neither; a couple of wise fools i’faith, to get children and know not one another.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: You weeping leaves, upon whose tender cheeks
Doth stand a flood of tears at my complaint,
And heard my vows and oaths.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Law, law, he has been a great swearer too; ’tis he, sister.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: For having overtook her, as I have seen a forward blood-hound, strip the swifter of the cry ready to seize his wished hopes, upon the sudden view
Struck with astonishment at his arrived prey,
Instead of seizure stands at fearful bay;
Or like to Marius’ soldiers, who o’ertook
The eyesight-killing Gorgon, at one look
Made everlasting stand; so feared my power
Whose cloud aspired the sun, dissolved a shower:
Pygmalion, then I tasted thy sad fate,
Whose ivory picture, and my fair were one,
Our dotage past imagination; then
I saw and felt desire,—

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Pox o’ your fingering! Did he feel, sister?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: —But enjoyed not;
Oh, fate, thou hadst thy days and nights to feed,
On calm affection, one poor sight was all,
Converts my pleasure to perpetual thrall,
Embracing thine, thou losest breath and desire,
So I relating mine, will here expire;
For here I vow to you, ye mournful plants,
Who were the first made happy by her fame,
Never to part hence, till I know her name.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Give me thy hand, sister, the child has found his father; this is he sure, as I am a man; had I been a woman, these kind words would have won me; I should have had a great belly too, that’s certain; well, I’ll speak to him; most honest and fleshly-minded gentleman, give me your hand, sir.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Ha! What art thou, that thus rude and boldly darest take notice of a wretch so much allied to misery as I am?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Nay, sir, for our alliance, I shall be found to be a poor brother-in-law of your worship’s; the gentlewoman you spoke on is my sister; you see what a clew she spreads; her name is Joan Go-to-’t, I am her elder, but she has been at it before me: ’tis a woman’s fault; pox o’ this bashfulness, come forward Jug, prithee speak to him.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Have you e’er seen me, lady?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Seen ye, ha, ha! It seems she has felt you too; here’s a young Go-to-’t a-coming, sir; she is my sister we all love to go to’;t as well as your worship; she’s a maid yet, but you may make her a wife when you please, sir.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: I am amazed with wonder: tell me, woman, what sin have you committed worthy this?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Do you not know me, sir?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Know thee! As I do thunder, hell, and mischief; witch, stallion, hag!

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I see he will marry her, he speaks so like a husband.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Death! I will cut out their tongues for this blasphemy. Strumpet, villain, where have you ever seen me?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Speak for yourself, with a pox to ye.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Slaves! I’ll make you curse yourselves for this temptation.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Oh, sir, if ever you did speak to me it was in smoother phrase, in fairer language.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Lightning consume me if I ever saw thee! My rage o’erflows my blood, all patience flies me.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Hold, I beseech you, sir; I have nothing to say to you.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Help, help! Murder, murder!

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: Make haste, sir, this way the sound came; it was a wood.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: See where she is, and the prince! The price of all our wishes.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: The prince, say ye? He’s made a poor subject of me, I am sure.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: Sweet prince, noble Uther, speak! How fare you, sir?

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Dear sir, recall yourself; your fearful absence hath won too much already on the grief of our sad king, from whom our laboring search hath had this fair success in meeting you.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: His silence and his looks argue distraction.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Nay, he’s mad, sure; he will not acknowledge my sister, nor the child neither.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Let us entreat your grace along with us; your sight will bring new life to the king your brother.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: Will you go, sir?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Yes, any whither, guide me, all’s hell I see,
Man may change air, but not his misery.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Lend me one word with you, sir.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well said, sister; he has a feather, and fair hangers too, this may be he.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: What would you, fair one?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Sure I have seen you in these woods ere this?

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Trust me, never; I never saw this place till at this time my friend conducted me.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: The more’s my sorrow then.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: Would I could comfort you: I am a bachelor, but it seems you have a husband; you have been foully o’ershot else.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: A woman’s fault; we are all subject to go to’t, sir.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: Oswold, away; the prince will not stir a foot without you.

speech.speaker: OSW.
speech.line: I am coming; farewell, woman.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: Prythee make haste.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Good sir, but one word with you ere you leave us.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: With me, fair soul?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: She’ll have a fling at him, too; the child must have a father.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Have you ne’er seen me, sir?

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: Seen thee! ’Sfoot! I have seen many fair faces in my time; prithee look up, and do not weep so; sure, pretty wanton, I have seen this face before.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: It is enough, though your ne’er see me more.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: ’Sfoot she’s fallen; this place is enchanted sure; look to the woman, fellow.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Oh, she’s dead! She’s dead! As you are a man stay and help, sir. Joan, Joan, sister Joan! Why Joan Go-to-’t, I say; will you cast away yourself, and your child, and me too? What do you mean, sister?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Oh, give me pardon, sir; ’twas too much joy oppressed my loving thoughts; I knew you were too noble to deny me; ha! Where is he?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Who, the gentleman? He’s gone, sister.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Oh! I am undone, then; run, and tell him I did but faint for joy; dear brother, haste; why dost thou stay? Oh, never cease till he give answer to thee.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: He! Which he? What do you call him tro?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Unnatural brother, shew me the path he took. Why dost thou dally? Speak, oh, which way went he?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: This way, that way, through the bushes there.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Were it through fire,
The journey’s easy, winged with sweet desire.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Hey day, there’s some hope of this yet; I’ll follow her for kindred’s sake; if she miss of her purpose now, she’ll challenge all she finds, I see, for if ever we meet with a two-legged creature in the whole kingdom, the child shall have a father, that’s certain.

scene.scenelocation: An antechamber at the British court.

stagedir.dir: Loud music. Enter Third and Fourth Captains with the sword and mace; Cador, Earl of Cornwall, Edwin, two Bishops, Aurelius, Ostorius, leading Artesia, crowned; Constantia, Modesta, Octa, Proximus a Magician, Lord Donobert, Earl of Gloucester, Oswald, Toclio, all pass over the stage; Manet Donobert, Earl of Gloucester, Edwin, and Cador, Earl of Cornwall.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Come, Gloster, I do not like this hasty marriage.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: She was quickly wooed and won. Not six days since arrived an enemy to sue for peace, and now crowned queen of Britain! This is strange.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Her brother, too, made as quick speed in coming, leaving his Saxons and his starved troops, to take the advantage whilst ’t was offered; ’fore heaven, I fear the king’s too credulous. Our army is discharged too.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Yes, and our general commanded home. Son Edwin, have you seen him since?

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: He’s come to court; but will not view the presence, nor speak unto the king, he’s so discontent at this so strange aliance with the Saxon, as nothing can persuade his patience.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: You know his humor will endure no check; no, if the king oppose it. All crosses feed both his spleen and his impatience; those affections are in him like powder, apt to inflame with every little spark, and blow up all his reason.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Edol of Chester is a noble soldier.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: So is he by the rod, ever most faithful to the king and kingdom. Howe’er his passions guide him.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: See where he comes, my lord.

speech.speaker: ALL. COURT.
speech.line: Welcome to court, brave Earl.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Do not deceive me by your flatteries. Is not the Saxon here? The league confirmed? The marriage ratified? The court divided with pagan infidels? The least part Christians, at least in their commands? Oh, the gods! It is a thought that takes away my sleep, and dulls my senses so, I scarcely know you. Prepare my horses, I’ll away to Chester.

speech.speaker: 1. ENG. CAPT.
speech.line: What shall we do with our companies, my lord?

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Keep them at home to increase cuckholds, and get some cases for your captainships, smooth up your brows, the wars have spoiled your faces, and few will now regard you.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Preserve your patience, sir.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Preserve your honors, lords, your country’s safety, your lives and lands from strangers. What black devil could so bewitch the king, so to discharge a royal army in the height of conquest—nay, even already made victorious—to give such credit to an enemy, a starved foe, a straggling fugitive, beaten beneath our feet, so low dejected, so servile, and so base, as hope of life had won them all to leave the land for ever?

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: It was the king’s will.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: It was your want of wisdom, that should have laid before his tender youth the dangers of a state, where foreign powers bandy for sovereignty with lawful kings, who being settled once, to assure themselves, will never fail to seek the blood and life of all competitors.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Your words sound well, my lord, and point at safety, both for the realm and us; but why did you, within whose power it lay, as general, with full commission to dispose the war, lend ear to parley with your weakened foe?

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Oh, the good gods!

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: And on that parley came this embassy.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: You will hear me.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Your letters did declare it to the king, both of the peace, and all conditions brought by this Saxon lady, whose fond love has thus bewitched him.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: I will curse you all as black as hell, unless you hear me; your gross mistake would make wisdom herself run madding through the streets, and quarrel with her shadow; death! Why killed ye not that woman?

speech.speaker: DONO. AND GLOU.
speech.line: Oh, my lord!

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: The great devil take me quick, had I been by, and all the women of the world were barren, she should have died ere he had married her on these conditions.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: It is not reason that directs you thus.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Then have I none, for all I have directs me; never was man so palpably abused, so basely marted, bought and sold to scorn, my honor, fame, and hopeful victories, the loss of time, expenses, blood, and fortunes, all vanished into nothing.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: This rage is vain, my lord. What the king does, nor they, nor you can help.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: My sword must fail me then.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: ’Gainst whom will you expose it?

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: What’s that to you? ‘gainst all the devils in hell, to guard my country.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: These are airy words.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Sir, you tread too hard upon my patience.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: I speak the duty of a subject’s faith, and say again had you been here in presence, what the king did, you had not dared to cross it,

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: I will trample on his life and soul that says it.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: My lord!

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Come, come.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Now, before heaven!

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Dear sir.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Not dare? Thou liest beneath thy lungs.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: No more, son Edwin.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: I have done, sir. I take my leave.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: But thou shall not. You shall take no leave of me, sir.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: For wisdom’s sake, my lord.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Sir, I’ll leave him, and you, and all of you, the court and king, and let my sword and friends shuffle for Edol’s safety. Stay you here, and hug the Saxons till they cut your throats, or bring the land to servile slavery.
Such yokes of baseness, Chester must not suffer,
Go, and repent betimes these foul misdeeds,
For in this league, all our whole kingdom bleeds,
Which I’ll prevent, or perish.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: See how his rage transports him!

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: These passions set apart, a braver soldier breathes not i’th’ world this day.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: I wish his own worth do not court his ruin.
The king must rule, and we must learn to obey,
True virtue still directs the noble way.

scene.scenelocation: Hall of state in the palace.

stagedir.dir: Loud music. Enter Aurelius, Artesia, Ostorius, Octa, Proximus, Toclio, Oswald, and Hermit.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Why is the court so dull? Methinks each room and angle of our palace should appear stuck full of objects fit for mirth and triumphs, to show our high content. Oswold, fill wine; must we begin the revels? Be it so, then, reach me the cup; I’ll now begin a health to our loved queen, the bright Artesia, and the royal Saxon king, our warlike brother; go and command all the whole court to pledge it; fill to the hermit there; most reverend Anselme, we’ll do thee honor first to pledge my queen.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: I drink no healths great king, and if I did, I would be loth to part with health, to those that have no power to give it back again.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Mistake not; it is the argument of love and duty to our queen and us.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: But he owes none, it seems.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: I do to vertue, madam: temperate minds
Covet that health to drink, which nature gives
In every spring to man: he that doth hold
His body but a tenement at will,
Bestows no cost but to repair what’s ill;
Yet if your healths, or heat of wine, fair princess,
Could this old frame, or these crazed limbs restore,
Or keep out death, or sickness, then fill more;
I’ll make fresh way for appetite; if no,
On such a prodigal who would wealth bestow.

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: He speaks not like a guest to grace a wedding.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: No, sir; but like an envious imposter.

speech.speaker: OCTA.
speech.line: A Christian slave; a cynic.

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: What virtue could decline your kingly spirit to such respect of him whose magic spells met with your vanquished troops, and turned your arms to that necessity of flight; which but for the despair of any hope to stand but by his charms, had been defeated in a bloody conquest?

speech.speaker: OCTA.
speech.line: ’Twas magic, hell-bred magic, did it, sir; and that’s a course, my lord, which we esteem in all our Saxon wars unto the last and lowest ebb of servile treachery.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Sure you are deceived: it was the hand of heaven, that in his virtue gave us victory. Is there a power in man that can strike fear thorough a general camp, or create spirits, in recreant bosoms, above present sense?

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: To blind the sense there may, with apparition of well-armed troops, which in themselves are air, formed into human shapes; and such that day were by that sorcerer raised to cross our fortunes.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: There is a law tells us, that words want force to make deeds void; examples must be shown by instances alike, ere I believe it.

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: ’Tis easily performed, believe me, sir. Propose your own desires, and give but way to what our magic here shall straight perform; and then let his or our deserts be censured.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: We could not wish a greater happiness than what this satisfaction brings with it: let him proceed, fair brother.

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: He shall, sir. Come, learned Proximus, this task be thine; let thy great charms confound the opinion this Christian, by his spells, hath falsely won.

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: Great king, propound your wishes, then: what person—of what state—what numbers—or how armed: please your thoughts; they shall appear before you.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Strange art! What think’st thou, reverend hermit?

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Let him go on, sir.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Wilt thou behold his cunning?

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Right gladly, sir, ’t will be my joy to tell,
That I was here to laugh at him and hell.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: I like thy confidence.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: His saucy impudence; proceed to the trial.

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: Speak your desires, my lord; and be it placed in any angle beneath the moon, the center of the earth, the sea, the air, the region of the fire, nay hell itself, and I’ll present it.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: We’ll have no sight so fearful, only this: if all thy art can reach it, show me here the two great champions of the Trojan war, Achilles and brave Hector, our great ancestor, both in their warlike habits, armor, shields, and weapons then in use for fight.

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: ’Tis done, my lord: command a halt and silence, as each man will respect his life or danger. Armel! Plesgeth!

stagedir.dir: Enter the spirits Armel and Plesgeth.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: Quid vis?

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: Attend me.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: The apparition comes: on our displeasure let all keep place and silence.

stagedir.dir: Drums within beat marches. Re-enter Proximus, bringing in Hector attired and armed after the Trojan manner; with target, sword, and battle axe, a Trumpet before him, and a Spirit in flame colors with a torch; at the other door Achilles, with his spear and falchion, a Trumpet and a Spirit in black before him. Trumpet sounds alarm, and they manage their weapons to begin the fight. After some charges the Hermit steps between them, at which, seeming amazed, the Spirits tremble. Thunder within.

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: What means this stay, bright Armel, Plesgeth? Why fear you and fall back? Renew the alarms, and enforce the combat, or hell and darkness circles you for ever.

speech.speaker: ARM.
speech.line: We dare not.

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: Ha!

speech.speaker: PLES.
speech.line: Our charms are all dissolved; Armel, away;
’Tis worse than hell to us while here we stay.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: What! At a nonplus, sir? Command them back for shame.

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: What power o’erawes may spells? Return, you hell-hounds; Armel, Plesgeth, double damnation seize you: by all the infernal powers, the prince of devils is in this hermit’s habit; what else could force my spirits quake or tremble thus?

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Weak argument to hide your want of skill.
Does the devil fear the devil, or war with hell?
They have not been acquainted long, it seems.
Know, misbelieving pagan, even that Power,
That overthrew your forces, still lets you see,
He only can controul both hell and thee.

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: Disgrace and mischief! I’l; enforce new charms, new spells and spirits raised from the low abyss of hell’s unbottomed depths.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: We have enough, sir; give o’er your charms; we’ll find some other time to praise your art. I dare not but acknowledge that heavenly power my heart stands witness to. Be not dismayed, my lords, at this disaster; nor thou, my fairest queen; we’ll change the scene to some more pleasing sports. Lead to your chamber:
Howe’er in this thy pleasures find a cross,
Our joy’s too fixèd here to suffer loss.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: Which I shall add to, sir, with news I bring. The prince, your brother, lives.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Ha!

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: And comes to grace this high and heaven-knit marriage.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Why dost thou flatter me, to make me think such happiness attends me?

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: His presence speaks my truth, sir.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: ’Fore me? ’tis he! Look, Gloster.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: A blessing beyond hope, sir.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Ha! ’tis he; welcome, my second comfort. Artesia, dearest love, it is my brother—my princely brother—all my kingdom’s hope: oh give him welcome, as thou lov’st my health.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: You have so free a welcome, sir, from me, as this your presence has such power, I swear o’er me a stranger, that I must forget my country, name, and friends, and count this place my joy and birthright.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: ’Tis she! ’tis she, I swear! Oh ye good gods, ’tis she! That face, within those woods where first I saw her, captivated my senses, and thus many months barred me from all society of men. How came she to this place, brother Aurelius? Speak that angel’s name—her heaven-blest name: oh speak it quickly, sir.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: It is Artesia, the royal Saxon princess.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: A woman, and no deity: no feigned shape
To mock the reason of admiring sense,
On whom a hope as low as mine may live,
Love, and enjoy; dear brother, may it not?

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: She is all the good or virtue thou canst name; my wife, my queen.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Ha! Your wife?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Which you shall find, sir; if that time and fortune may make my love but worthy of your trial.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Oh!

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: What troubles you, dear brother? Why with so strange and fixed an eye dost thou behold my joys?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: You are not well, sir.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Yes, yes. Oh, you immortal powers, why has poor man so many entrances for sorrow to creep in at, when our sense is much too weak to hold his happiness? Oh, say I was born deaf; and let your silence confirm in me the knowing my defect; at least be charitable to conceal my sin, for hearing is no less in me, dear brother.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: No more; I see thou art a rival in
The joys of my high bliss: come, my Artesia,
The day’s most praised when ’tis eclipsed by night,
Great good must have as great ill opposite.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Stay, hear but a word;—yet now I think on’t,
This is your wedding-night and were it mine,
I should be angry with least loss of time.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Envy speaks no such words; has no such looks.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Sweet rest unto you both.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Lights unto our nuptial chamber.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Could you speak so,
I would not fear how much my grief did grow.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Lights to our chamber; on, on, set on.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: “Could you speak so,
I would not fear how much my grief did grow.”
Those were her very words. Sure I am waking;
She wrung me by the hand, and spake them to me
With a most passionate affection;
Perhaps she loves, and now repents her choice
In marriage with my brother. Oh, fond man,
How darest thou trust thy traitor’s thoughts
Thus to betray thyself? ’T was but a waking dream
Wherein thou mad’st thy wishes speak; not her,
In which thy foolish hopes strive to prolong
A wretched being; so sickly children play
With health-loved toys, which for a time delay,
But do not cure the fit: be then a man;
Meet that destruction which thou canst not fly
From: not to live, make it thy best to die;
And call her now, whom thou didst hope to wed,
Thy brother’s wife; thou art too near akin,
And such an act above all name’s a sin
Not to be blotted out, heaven pardon me;
She’s banished from my bosom now for ever,
To lowest ebbs, men justly hope a flood,
When vice grows barren, all desires are good.

stagedir.dir: Enter a Waiting Gentlewoman, with a Jewel.

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: The noble prince, I take it, sir?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: You speak me what I should be, lady.

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: Know by that name, sir, queen Artesia greets you.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Alas, good virtue, how is she mistaken.

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: Commending her affection in this jewel, sir.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: She binds my service to her: ha! A jewel; ’tis a fair one, trust me; and methinks it much resembles something I have seen with her.

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: It is an artificial crab, sir.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: A creature that goes backward.

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: True, from the way it looks.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: There is no moral in it aludes to herself?

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: ’Tis your construction gives you that, sir; she’s a woman.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: And like this may use her legs and eyes two several ways.

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: Just like the sea-crab, which on the mussel preys, whilst he bills at a stone.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Pretty, in troth; prithee tell me, art thou honest?

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: I hope I seem no other, sir.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: And those that seem so, are sometimes bad enough.

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: If they will accuse themselves for want of witness, let them; I am not so foolish.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: I see thou art wise; come, speak me truly; what is the greatest sin?

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: That which man never acted, what has been done
Is as the least, common to all as one.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Dost think thy lady is of that opinion?

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: She’s a bad scholar, else; I have brought her up, and she dares owe me still.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Ay, ’tis a fault in greatness: they dare owe many ere they pay one; but darest thou expose thy scholar to my examining?

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: Yes, in good troth, sir, and pray put her to’t too; ’tis a hard lesson if she answer it not.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Thou know’st the hardest.

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: As far as woman may, sir.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: I commend thy plainness; when wilt thou bring me to thy lady?

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: Next opportunity I attend you, sir.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Thanks, take this, and commend me to her.

speech.speaker: WAIT.
speech.line: Think of your sea-crab, sir, I pray.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Oh, by any means, lady. What shall all this tend to? If it be love or lust that thus incites her, the sin is horrid and incestuous; if to betray my life, what hopes she by it? Yes, it may be a practice ’twixt themselves to expel the Britons and ensure the state through our destruction; all this may be valid with a deeper reach in villainy than all my thoughts can guess at; however,—
I will confer with her, and if I find
Lust hath giv’n life to envy in her mind,
I may prevent the danger; so men wise
By the same step by which they fell, may rise.
Vices are virtues, if so thought and seen,
And trees with foulest roots, branch soonest green.

scene.scenelocation: Before the palace of King Aurelius.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Come, sister, thou that art all fool, all madwoman.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Prythee have patience, we are now at court.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: At court! Ha, ha, that proves thy madness; was there ever any woman in thy taking traveled to court for a husband? ’s lid, ’tis enough for them to get children, and the city to keep ’em, and the country to find nurses: everything must be done in its due place, sister.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Be but content awhile, for sure I know this journey will be happy. Oh, dear brother, this night my sweet friend came to comfort me; I saw him, and embraced him in mine arms.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Why did you not hold him, and call me to help you?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Alas! I thought I had been with him still, but when I waked—

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ah, pox of all loggerheads! Then you were but in a dream all this while, and we may still go look for him. Well, since we are come to court, cast your cat’s eyes about you, and either find him out you dreamed on, or some other, for I’ll trouble myself no further.

stagedir.dir: Enter Lord Donobert, Cador, Earl of Cornwall, Edwin, and Toclio.

speech.line: See, see, here comes more courtiers; look about you; come, pray view ’em all well; the old man has none of the marks about him, the others have both swords and feathers; what thinkest thou of that tall young gentleman?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: He much resembles him; but sure my friend, brother, was not so high of stature.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Oh, beast, wast thou got with child with a short thing, too?

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Come, come, I’ll hear no more on’t: go, lord Edwin, tell her this day her sister shall be married to Cador, aarl of Cornwall; so shall she to thee, brave Edwin, if she’ll have my blessing.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: She is addicted to a single life; she will not hear of marriage.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Tush, fear it not; go you from me to her; use your best skill, my lord; and if you fail, I have a trick shall do it: haste, haste about it.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Sir, I am gone; my hope is in your help more than my own.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: And, worthy Toclio, to your care I must commend this business, for lights and music, and what else is needful.

speech.speaker: TOC.
speech.line: I shall, my lord.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: We would entreat a word, sir; come forward, sister.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Donobert, Toclio, and Cador, Earl of Cornwall.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: What lackest thou, fellow?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I lack a father for a child, sir.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: How! A godfather?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: No, sir, we mean the own father; it may be you, sir, for anything we know: I think the child is like you.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Like me! Prythee where is it?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Nay, ’tis not born yet, sir, ’tis forthcoming you see; the child must have a father: what do you think of my sister?

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Why I think if she ne’er had husband, she’s a whore, and thou a fool; farewell.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I thank you, sir. Well, pull up thy heart, sister; if there be any law in the court this fellow shall father it, ’cause he uses me so scurvily. There’s a great wedding towards they say; we’ll among them for a husband for thee.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Nichodemus with a Letter.

speech.line: If we miss there, I’ll have another bout with him that abused me. See! Look, there comes another hat and feather; this should be a close lecher; he’s reading of a love-letter.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: Earl Cador’s marriage, and a masque to grace it; so, so. This night shall make me famous for presentments. How now, what are you?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: A couple of Great Britons, you may see by our bellies, sir.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: And what of this, sir?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Why thus the matter stands, sir. There’s one of your courtiers’ hunting nags has made a gap through another man’s enclosure Now, sir, here’s the question; who should be at charge of a furze bush to stop it?

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: Ha, ha, this is out of my element; the law must end it.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Your worship says well; for surely I think some lawyer had a hand in the business, we have such a troublesom issue.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: But what’s thy business with me now?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Nay, sir, the business is done already, you may see by my sister’s belly.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: Oh, now I find thee, this gentlewoman it seems has been humbled.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: As low as the ground would give her leave, sir, and your worship knows this; though there be many fathers without children, yet to have a child without a father were most unnatural.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: That’s true, i’faith, I never heard of a child yet that e’er begot his father.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Why, true, you say wisely, sir.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: And therefore I conclude, that he that got the child, is, without all question, the father of it.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ay, now you come to the matter, sir; and our suit is to your worship for the discovery of this father.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: Why, lives he in the court here?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Yes, sir, and I desire but marriage.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: And does the knave refuse it? Come, come, be merry, wench, he shall marry thee, and keep the child too, if my knighthood can do anything; I am bound by mine orders to help distressed ladies, and can there be a greater injury to a woman with child, than to lack a father for’t? I am ashamed of your simpleness. Come, come, give me a courtier’s fee for my pains, and I’ll be thy advocate myself, and justice shall be found, nay, I’ll sue the law for it; but give me my ee first.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: If all the money I have i’ the world will do it, you shall have it, sir.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: An angel does it.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Nay, there’s two, for your better eye sight, sir.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: Why, well said; give me thy hand, wench, I’ll teach thee a trick for all this shall get a father for thy child presently, and this it is, mark now; you meet a man as you meet me now, thou claimest marriage of me, and layest the child to my charge; I deny it; pish, that’s nothing, hold thy claim fast, thy words carry it, and no law can withstand it.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Is’t posslble?

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: Past all opposition, her own word carries it; let her challenge any man, the child shall call him father; there’s a trick for your money now.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Troth, sir, we thank you; we’ll make use of your trick, and go no further to seek the child a father, for we challenge you, sir. Sister, lay it to him, he shall marry thee, I shall have a worshipful old man to my brother.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: Ha, ha! I like thy pleasantness.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Nay, indeed, sir, I do challenge you.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: You think we jest, sir?

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: Ay, by my troth do I, I like thy wit, i’faith, thou shalt live at court with me; didst never hear of Nichodemus Nothing? I am the man.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Nothing! ’s lid we are out again, thou wert never got with child with nothing, sure.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: I know not what to say.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: Never grieve, wench; show me the man, and process shall fly out.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: ’Tis enough for us to find the children, we look that you should find the father; and therefore, either do us justice, or we’ll stand to our first challenge.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: Would you have justice without an adversary? Unless you can show me the man, I can do no good in it.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Why, then, I hope you’ll do us no harm, sir, you’ll restore my money.

speech.speaker: NOTH.
speech.line: What! My fee? Marry, law forbid it; find out the party, and you shall have justice,
Your fault closed up, and all shall be amended,
The child his father, and the law ended.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well, he has deserved his fee indeed, for he has brought our suit to a quick end, I promise you, and yet the child has never a father; nor have we more money to seek after him, a shame of all lecherous plackets; now you look like a cat had newly kittened, what will you do, tro? Follow me no further, lest I beat your brains out.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Impose upon me any punishment, rather than leave me now.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well, I think I am bewitched with thee. I cannot find in my heart to forsake her; there was never sister would have abused a poor brother as thou hast done; I have even pined away with fretting, there’s nothing but flesh and bones about me; well, and I had my money again, it were some comfort—hark, sister,
does it not thunder?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Oh yes, most fearfully, what shall we do, brother?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Marry, e’en get some shelter ere the storm catch us; away, let’s away, I prithee.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Devil in man’s habit, richly attired, his feet and his head horrid.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Ha! ’tis he, stay, brother, dear brother stay.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: What’s the matter now?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: My love, my friend is come; yonder he goes.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Where, where, show me where? I’ll stop him, if the devil be not in him.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Look there, look yonder; oh, dear friend, pity my distress, for heaven and goodness do but speak to me.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: She calls me, and yet drives me headlong from her.
Poor mortal, thou and I are much uneven,
Thou must not speak of goodness, nor of heaven,
If I confer with thee; but be of comfort;
Whilst men do breathe, and Britain’s name be known,
The fatal fruit thou bear’st within thy womb,
Shall here be famous till the day of doom.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: ’S lid, who’s that talks so? I can see nobody.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Then thou art blind, or mad; see where he goes, and beckons me to come; oh, lead me forth, I’ll follow thee in spite of fear or death.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Oh brave, she’ll run to the devil for a husband; she’s stark mad sure, and talks to a shadow, for I could see no substance. Well, I’ll after her, the child was got by chance, and the father must be found at all adventure.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Oh, reverend sir, by you my heart hath reached
At the large hopes of holy piety,
And ’twas for this I craved your company,
Here in your sight religiously to vow,
My chaste thoughts up to heav’n, and make you now
The witness of my faith.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Angels asslst thy hopes!

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: What means my love? Thou art my promised wife.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: To part with willingly what friends and life
Can make no good assurance of.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Oh find remorse,
Fair soul, to love and merit, and yet recant thy vow.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Never; this world and I are parted now for ever.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: To find the way to bliss, oh happy woman,
Thou’st learned the hardest lesson well, I see;
Now show thy fortitude and constancy,
Let these thy friends thy sad departure weep,
Thou shalt but lose the wealth thou couldst not keep:
My contemplation calls me, I must leave ye.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Oh, reverend sir, persuade not her to leave me.

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: My lord, I do not, nor to cease to love you,
I only pray her faith may fixèd stand,
Marriage was blest, I know, with heaven’s own hand.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: You hear him, lady, ’tis not a virgin state, but sanctity of life, must make you happy.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Good sir, you say you love me; gentle Edwin, even by that love, I do beseech you leave me.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Think of your father’s tears, your weeping friends, whom cruel grief makes pale and bloodless all for you.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Would I were dead to all.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Why do you weep?

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Oh, who would live to see
How men with care and cost seek misery.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Why do you seek it then? What joy, what pleasure
Can give you comfort in a single life?

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: The contemplation of a happy death, which is to me so pleasing that I think no torture could divert me. What’s this world wherein you’d have me walk, but a sad passage to a dread judgment-seat, from whence even now we are but bailed upon our good abearing, till those great sessions come, when death the crier
Will surely summon us, and all t’appear,
To plead us guilty, or our bail to clear.
What music’s this?

stagedir.dir: Enter Two Bishops, Lord Donobert, Earl of Gloucester, Cador, Earl of Cornwall, Constantia, Oswald, and Toclio.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Oh now resolve and think upon my love; this sounds the marriage of your beauteous sister, virtuous Constantia, with the noble Cador: look, and behold this pleasure.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Cover me with night,
It is a vanity not worth the sight.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: See, see, she’s yonder; pass on son Cador. Daughter Constantia, I beseech you all, unless she first move speech, salute her not. Edwin, what good success?

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Nothing as yet, unless this object take her.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: See, see, her eye is fixed upon her sister;
Seem careless all, and take no notice of her:
On there afore; come, my Constantia.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Not speak to me, nor deign to cast an eye,
To look on my despisèd poverty?
I must be more charitable; pray stay, lady;
Are not you she whom I did once call sister?

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: I did acknowledge such a name to one
Whilst she was worthy of it, in whose folly,
Since you neglect your fame and friends together,
In you I drowned a sister’s name for ever.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Your looks did speak no less.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: It now begins to work; this sight has moved her.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: I knew this trick would take, or nothing.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Though you disdain in me a sister’s name, yet charity, methinks, should be so strong to instruct ere you reject. I am a wretch, even follies instance, who perhaps have erred, not having known the goodness that bears so high and fair a show in you, which being expressed,
I may recant this low despisèd life,
And please those friends whom I have moved to grief.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: She is coming, ’i faith; be merry, Edwin.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Since you desire instruction, you shall have it; what is it should make you thus desire to live vowed to a single life?

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Because I know I cannot fly from death;
O, my good sister, I beseech you hear me:
This world is but a masque, catching weak eyes,
With what is not ourselves but our disguise:
A vizard that falls off, the dance being done,
And leaves death’s glass for all to look upon:
Our best happiness here, lasts but a night,
Whose burning tapers make false ware seem right;
Who knows not this, and will not now provide
Some better shift before his shame be spied,
And knowing this vain world at last will leave him,
Shake off these robes that help but to deceive him.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Her words are powerful; I am amazed to hear her!

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Her soul’s enchanted with infected spells.
Leave her, best girl, for now in thee
I’ll seek the fruits of age, posterity.
Out of my sight; sure I was half asleep,
Or drunk, when I begot thee.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Good sir, forbear. What say you to that, sister?
The joy of children, a blest mother’s name!
Oh, who without much grief can lose such fame?

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Who can enjoy it without sorrow rather?
And that most certain where the joy’s unsure,
Seeing the fruit that we beget endure
So many miseries, that oft we pray
The heavens to shut up their afflicted day;
At best we do but bring forth heirs to die,
And fill the coffins of our enemy.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Oh, my soul!

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Hear her no more, Constantia:
She’s sure bewitched with error; leave her, girl.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Then must I leave all goodness, sir. Away,
Stand off, I say.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: How’s this?

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: I have no father, friend, no husband now;
All are but borrowed robes in which we masque
To waste and spend the time, when all our life
Is but one good between two ague-days,
Which from the first, ere we have time to praise,
A second fever takes us. Oh, my best sister!
My soul’s eternal friend! Forgive the rashness of my distempered tongue; for how could she knew not herself, know thy felicity, from which worlds cannot now remove me?

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Art thou mad too, fond woman? What’s thy meaning?

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: To seek eternal happiness in heaven, which all this world affords not.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Think of thy vow: thou art my promised wife.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Pray trouble me no further.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Strange alteration!

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Why do you stand at gaze, you sacred priests? You holy men, be equal to the gods, and consummate my marriage with this woman.

speech.speaker: 1. BISH.
speech.line: Herself gives bar, my lord, to your desires and our performance; ’tis against the law and orders of the church to force a marriage.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: How am I wronged! Was this your trick, my lord?

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: I am abused past sufferance; grief and amazement strive which sense of mine shall lose her being first; yet let me call thee daughter.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Me, wife!

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Your words are air, you speak of want to wealth,
And wish her sickness newly raised to health.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Bewitched girls, tempt not an old man’s fury, that hath no strength to uphold his feeble age but what your sights give life to; oh, beware, and do not make me curse you.

speech.speaker: MOD.
speech.line: Dear father, here at your feet we kneel; grant us but this, that in your sight and hearing the good hermit may plead our cause; which, if it shall not give such satisfaction as your age desires, we will submit to you.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: You gave us life, save not our bodies but our souls from death.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: This gives some comfort yet; rise with my blessings. Have patience, noble Cador; worthy Edwin, send for the hermit that we may confer, for sure religion ties you not to leave
Your careful father thus; if so it be,
Take you content, and give all grief to me.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: Mix light and darkness, earth and heaven dissolve, be of one piece again, aad turn to chaos. Break all your works you powers, and spoil the world; or, if you will maintain earth still, give way and life to this abortive birth now coming, whose fame shall add unto your oracles. Lucina, Hecate, dreadful queen of night, bright Proserpine, be pleased for Ceres’ love, from Stygian darkness summon up the fates,
And in a moment bring them quickly hither,
Lest death do vent her birth and her together.
Assist you spirits of infernal deeps, squint-eyed Erietho, midnight Incubus!

stagedir.dir: Enter Lucina, and the Three Fates.

speech.line: Rise, rise to aid this birth prodigious. Thanks, Hecate, hail sister to the gods, there lies your way, haste with the Fates, and help! Give quick despatch unto her laboring throes, to bring this mixture of infernal seed to humane being.
And to beguile her pains till back you come,
Antics shall dance, and music fill the room.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: Thanks, queen of shades.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Farewell, great servant to the infernal king,
In honor of this child the Fates shall bring
All their assisting powers of knowledge, arts,
Learning, wisdom, all the hidden parts
Of all-admiring prophecy, to foresee
The event of times to come, his art shall stand
A wall of brass to guard the Britain land;
Even from this minute all his art appears
Manlike in judgment, person, state, and years;
Upon his breast the Fates have fixed his name;
And since his birthplace was this forest here,
They now have named him Merlin Silvester.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: And Merlin’s name in Britain aye shall live,
Whilst men inhabit here, or fate can give
Power to amazing wonder; Envy shall weep,
And Mischief sit and shake her ebon wings,
Whilst all the world of Merlin’s magic sings.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well, I wonder how my poor sister does after all this thundering! I think she’s dead, for I can hear no tidings of her. Those woods yield small comfort to her: I could meet nothing but a swineherd’s wife, keeping hogs by the forest side; but neither she nor none of her sows would stir a foot to help us. Indeed, I think she durst not trust herself under the trees with me, for I must needs confess I offered some kindness to her: well, I would fain know what’s become of my sister; if she have brought me a young cousin, his face may be a picture to find his father by. So ho, sister Joan! Joan Go-to-’t, where art thou?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Here, here, brother. Stay but awhile. I come to thee.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: O brave! She’s alive still. I know her voice she speaks, and speaks cheerfully, methinks: how now? What moon-calf has she got with her?

stagedir.dir: Enter Joan and Merlin, with a book.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Come, my dear Merlin, why dost thou fix thine eye so deeply on that book?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: To sound the depth of art, of learning, wisdom, knowledge.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Oh my dear, dear son, those studies fit thee when thou art a man.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Why, mother, I can be but half a man at best,
And that is your mortality, the rest
In me is spirit; ’tis not meat, nor time,
That gives this growth and bigness; no, my years
Shall be more strange than yet my birth appears.
Look, mother, there’s my uncle.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: How dost thou know him, son? Thou never saw’st him.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Yet, I know him and know the pains he has taken for ye to find out my father. Give me your hand, good uncle.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ha, ha, I’d laugh at that, i’faith! Do you know me, sir?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Yes, by the same token that even now you kissed the swineherd’s wife i’the woods, and would have done more if she would have let you, uncle.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: A witch! A witch! A witch! Sister, rid him out of your company; he is either a witch or a conjuror; he could never have known this else.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Pray love him, brother; he is my son.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ha, ha! This is worse than all the rest, i’faith! By his beard he is more like your husband: let me see, is your great belly gone?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Yes, and this the happy fruit.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: What, this artichoke? A child born with a beard on his face?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Yes, and strong legs to go, and teeth to eat.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: You can nurse up yourself, then. There’s some charges saved for soap and candle: ’s lid, I have heard of some that has been born with teeth, but never none with such a talking tongue before.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Come, come, you must use him kindly, brother; did you but know his worth, you would make much of him.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Make much of a monkey! This is worse than Tom Thumb; a child to speak, eat, and go the first hour of his birth; nay, such a baby as had need of a barber before he was born, too; why, sister, this is monstrous, and shames all our kindred.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: That thus ‘gainst nature and our common births, he comes thus furnished to salute the world, is power of Fates, and gift of his great father.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Why, of what profession is your father, sir?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: He keeps a hot-house in the Low Countries; will you see him, sir?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: See him! Why, sister, has the child found his father?

speech.speaker: MERL.
