speech.line: Yes, and I’ll fetch him, uncle.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Do not uncle me till I know your kindred: ’fore my conscience some baboon begot thee: surely thou art horribly deceived, sister, this urchin cannot be of thy breeding: I shall be ashamed to call him cousin, though his father be a gentleman.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Now, my kind uncle, see,
The child has found his father—this is he.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: The devil it is! Ha, ha! Is this your sweetheart, sister? Have we run through the country, haunted the city, and examined the court, to find out a gallant with a hat and feather, and a silken sword, and golden hangers, and do you now bring me to a ragamuffin with a face like a frying-pan?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Fie, brother, you mistake; behold him better.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: How’s this? Do you juggle with me; or are mine eyes matches? Hat and feather, sword, and hangers and all! This is a gallant, indeed, sister; this has all the marks of him we look for.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: And you have found him now. Sir, give me your hand. I now must call you brother.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Not till you have married my sister. For all this while she’s but your whore, sir.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: Thou art too plain. I’ll satisfy that wrong to her, and thee, and all, with liberal hand. Come, why art thou fearful?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Nay, I am not afraid, and you were the devil, sir.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: Thou need’st not; keep with thy sister still, and I’ll supply your wants. You shall lack nothing that gold and wealth can purchase.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Thank you, brother. We have gone many a weary step to find you. You may be a husband for a lady, for you are far fetched and dear bought, I assure you. Pray how should I call your son, my cousin, here?

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: His name is Merlin.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Merlin! Your hand, cousin Merlin. For your father’s sake I accept you to my kindred, but if you grow in all things as your beard does, you will be talked on. By your mother’s side, cousin, you come of the Go-to-’ts, Suffolk bred. But our standing house is at Hockley-i’-the-Hole, and Leyton-Buzzard. For your father, no doubt you may from him claim titles of worship, but I cannot describe it. I think his ancestors came first from Hell-bree, in Wales, cousin.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: No matter whence we do derive our name;
All Brittany shall ring of Merlin’s fame,
And wonder at his acts. Go hence to Wales;
There live awhile; there Vortiger, the king,
Builds castles and strongholds which cannot stand
Unless supported by young Merlin’s hand.
There shall thy fame begin, wars are a-breeding.
The Saxons practice treason, yet unseen,
Which shortly shall break out. Fair love, farewell:
Dear son, and brother, here must I leave you all;
Yet still I will be near at Merlin’s call.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Will you go, uncle?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Yes, I’ll follow you, cousin. Well, I do most horribly begin to suspect my kindred: this brother-in-law of mine is the devil, sure; and though he hide his horns with his hat and feather, I spied his cloven foot for all his cunning.

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: Come, come, time calls our close complots to action. Go, Proximus, with winged speed fly hence. Hie thee to Wales. Salute great Vortiger with these our letters. Bid the king to arms. Tell him we have new friends, more forces landed in Norfolk and Northumberland. Bid him make haste to meet us. If he keep his word we’ll part the realm between us.

speech.speaker: OCTA.
speech.line: Bend all thine art to quit that late disgrace the Christian hermit gave thee. Make thy revenge both sure and home.

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: That thought, sir, spurs me on till I have wrought their swift destruction.

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: Go, then, and prosper. Octa, be vigilant. Speak, are the forts possessed? The guards made sure? Revolve, I pray, on how large consequence the bare event and sequel of our hopes jointly consists, that have embarked our lives upon the hazard of the least miscarriage.

speech.speaker: OCTA.
speech.line: All’s sure; the queen your sister, hath contrived the cunning plot so sure, as at an instant the brothers shall be both surprised and taken.

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: And both shall die, yet one awhile must live, till we by him have gathered strength and power to meet bold Edol, their stern general, that now, contrary to the king’s command, hath reunited all his cashiered troops, and this way beats his drums to threaten us.

speech.speaker: OCTA.
speech.line: Then our plot’s discovered.

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: Come, thou’rt a fool: his army and his life is given unto us. Where is the queen, my sister?

speech.speaker: OCTA.
speech.line: In conference with the prince.

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: Bring the guards nearer, all is fair and good,
Their conference I hope shall end in blood.

scene.scenelocation: An antechamber at the British court.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Come, come, you do but flatter; what you term love is but a dream of blood, wakes with enjoying, and with open eyes forgot, condemned, and lost.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: I must be wary; her words are dangerous.
True, we’ll speak of love no more, then.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Nay, if you will you may,
’Tis but in jest, and yet so children play
With fiery flames, and covet what is bright,
But feeling the effects, abhor the light;
Pleasure is like a building, the more high,
The narrower still it grows; cedars do die
Soonest at top.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: How does your instance suit?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: From art and nature to make sure the root,
And lay a fast foundation, ere I try
The uncertain changes of a wavering sky.
Make your example thus—You have a kiss—
Was it not pleasing?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Above all name to express it.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Yet now the pleasure’s gone, and you have lost
Your joy’s possesslon.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Yet when you please this flood may ebb again.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: But where it never ebbs, there runs the main.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Who can attain such hopes?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: I’ll show the way to it; give me a taste
Once more, of what you may enjoy.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Impudent whore!
I were more false than atheism can be,
Should I not call this high felicity.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: If I should trust your faith, alas! I fear
You soon would change belief.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: I would covet martyrdom to make it confirmed.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Give me your hand on that; you’ll keep your word?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: I will.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Enough; help, husband! King Aurelius, help!
Rescue betrayed Artesia!

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Nay, then ’tis I that am betrayed, I see,
Yet with thy blood I’ll end thy treachery.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: How now! What troubles you? Is this you, sir, that but even now would suffer martyrdom to win your hopes, and is there now such terror in names of men to fright you? Nay, then, I see what mettle you are made on.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Ha! Was it but trial? Then I ask your pardon. What a dull slave I was to be so fearful!—I’ll trust her now no more, yet try the utmost—
I am resolved no brother, no man breathing, were he my blood’s begetter, should withhold me from your love; I’d leap into his bosom, and from his breast pull forth that happiness.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Ay, now you speak a lover like a prince.
Treason! Treason!

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Again!

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Help, Saxon princes! Treason!

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: Rescue the queen! Strike down the villain.

stagedir.dir: Enter Edol, Aurelius, Lord Donobert, Cador, Earl of Cornwall, Edwin, Toclio; Oswald at the opposite side.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Call in the guards: the prince in danger!
Fall back, dear sir, my breast shall buckler you.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Beat down their weapons.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Slave, wert thou made of brass, my sword shall bite thee.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Withdraw on pain of death: where is the traitor?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Oh, save your life, my lord! Let it suffice
My beauty forced my own captivity.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Who did attempt to wrong thee?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Hear me, sir!

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Oh, my sad soul! Was’t thou?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Oh, do not stay to speak; one minute’s stay
Prevents a second speech for ever.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Make our guard strong. My dear Artesia, let us know thy wrongs, and our own dangers.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: The prince your brother, with these Briton lords, have all agreed to take me hence by force, and marry me to him.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: The devil shall wed thee first. Thy baseness and thy lust confound and rot thee.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: He courted me even now, and in mine ear shamed not to plead his most dishonest love, and their attempts to seize your sacred person, either to shut you up within some prison, or which is worse, I fear to murder you.

speech.speaker: ALL. BRIT.
speech.line: ’Tis false as hell.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: And as foul as she is.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: You know me, sir?

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Yes, deadly sin, we know you, and shall discover all your villainy.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Chester, forbear.

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: Their treasons, sir, are plain. Why are their soldiers lodged so near the court?

speech.speaker: OCTA.
speech.line: Nay, why came he in arms so suddenly?

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: You fleering antics, do not wake my fury.

speech.speaker: OCTA.
speech.line: Fury!

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Ratsbane, do not urge me.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Good sir, keep farther from them.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Oh my sick heart,
She is a witch by nature, devil by art.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Bite thine own sland’rous tongue, ’tis thou art false;
I have observed your passions long ere this.

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: Stand on your guard, my lord; we are your friends, and all our force is yours.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: To spoil and rob the kingdom.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Sir, be silent.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Silent! How long? Till Doomsday? Shall I stand by and hear mine honor blasted with foul treason, the state half-lost, and your life endangered, yet be silent?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Yes, my blunt lord, unless you speak your treasons. Sir, let your guards, as traitors, seize them all, and then let tortures and devulsive racks force a confession from them.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Wild-fire and brimstone eat thee! Hear me, sir.

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: Sir, I’ll not hear you.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: But you shall not hear me! Were the world’s monarch, Cæsar, living, he should hear me. I tell you, sir, these serpents have betrayed your life and kingdom: does not every day bring tidings of more swarms of lousy knaves, the offal fugitives of barren Germany, that land upon our coasts, and have by our neglect settled in Norfolk and Northumberland?

speech.speaker: OST.
speech.line: They come as aids and safeguards to the king.

speech.speaker: OCTA.
speech.line: Has he not need, when Vortiger’s in arms, and you raise powers, ’tis thought to join with him?

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Peace, you pernicious rat.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Prythee, forbear.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Away! Suffer a gilded rascal, a low-bred despicable creeper, an insulting toad, to spit his venom in my face!

speech.speaker: OCTA.
speech.line: Sir, sir.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Do not reply, you cur, for, by the gods, though the king’s presence guard thee, I shall break all patience, and like a lion roused to spoil, shall run foul-mouthed upon thee, and devour thee quick. Speak, sir, will you forsake these scorpions, or stay till they have stung you to the heart?

speech.speaker: AUR.
speech.line: You are traitors all; this is our wife, our queen; brother Ostorius, troop your Saxons up, we’ll hence to Winchester, raise more powers, to man with strength the castle Camelot: go hence false men, join you with Vortiger, the murderer of our brother Constantine: we’ll hunt both him and you with dreadful vengeance.
Since Britain fails, we’ll trust to foreign friends,
And guard our person from your trait’rous ends.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Aurelius, Ostorius, Toclio, Octa, and Oswald.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: He’s sure bewitched.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: What counsel now for safety?

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Only this, sir, with all the speed we can, preserve the person of the king and kingdom.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Which to effect, ’tis best march hence to Wales, and set on Vortiger before he joins his forces with the Saxons.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: On, then, with speed for Wales and Vortiger; that tempest once o’erblown, we come, Ostorius, to meet thy traitorous Saxons, thee and them, that with advantage thus have won the king to back your factions, and to work our ruin,
This by the gods, and my good sword, I’ll set
In bloody lines upon thy burgonet.

scene.scenelocation: Before a ruined castle in Wales.

stagedir.dir: Enter Clown, Merlin, and a Little Antic Spirit.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: How now, uncle, why do you search your pockets so? Do you miss anything?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ha! Cousin Merlin, I hope your beard does not overgrow your honesty; I pray remember you are made up of sister’s thread; I am your mother’s brother, whoever was your father.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Why, wherein can you task my duty, uncle?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Yourself, or your page it must be; I have kept no other company, since your mother bound your head to my protectorship; I do feel a fault of one side; either it was that sparrow-hawk, or a cast of Merlin’s, for I find a covey of cardecus sprung out of my pocket.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Why, do you want any money, uncle? Sirrah, had you any from him?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Deny it not, for my pockets are witness against you.

speech.speaker: SPIR.
speech.line: Yes, I had, to teach you better wit to look to it.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Pray use your fingers better, and my wit may serve as it is, sir.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Well, restore it.

speech.speaker: SPIR.
speech.line: There it is.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ay, there’s some honesty in this; ’twas a token from your invisible father, cousin, which I would not have to go invisibly from me again.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Well, you are sure you have it now, uncle?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Yes, and mean to keep it now from your page’s filching fingers, too.

speech.speaker: SPIR.
speech.line: If you have it so sure, pray show it me again.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Yes, my little juggler, I dare show it. Ha! Cleanly conveyance again, ye have no invisible fingers have ye? ’Tis gone certainly.

speech.speaker: SPIR.
speech.line: Why, sir, I touched you not.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Why, look you, uncle, I have it now.How ill do you look to it! Here, keep it safer.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ha, ha! This is fine i’faith, I must keep some other company if you have these sleights of hand.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Come, come, uncle, ’tis all my art, which shall not offend you, sir. Only I give you a taste of it to show you sport.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Oh, but ’tis ill jesting with a man’s pocket though. But I am glad to see you, cunning cousin, for now I’ll warrant thee a living till thou diest. You have heard the news in Wales here?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Uncle, let me prevent your care and counsel, ’t will give you better knowledge of my cunning. You would prefer me now, in hope of gain, to Vortiger, king of the Welsh Britons, to whom are all the artists summoned now, that seeks the secrets of futurity, the bards, the druids, wizards, conjurers, not an Aurasper with his whistling spells, no Capuomanster with his musty fumes.
No witch or juggler but is thither sent,
To calculate the strange and feared event
Of this prodigious castle now in building,
Where all the labors of the painful day
are ruined still i’th’ night, and to this place you would have me go.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well, if thy mother were not my sister, I would say she was a witch that begot this. But this is thy father, not thy mother-wit. Thou hast taken away my tale into thy mouth, and spake my thoughts before me. Therefore away, shuffle thyself amongst the conjurers, and be a made man before thou comest to age.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Nay, but stay, uncle, you overslip my dangers: the prophesies and all the cunning wizards have certified the king, that his castle can never stand, till the foundation’s laid with mortar, tempered with the fatal blood of such a child whose father was no mortal.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: What’s this to thee? If the devil were thy father, was not thy mother born at Carmarden? Diggon for that then, and then it must be a child’s blood, and who will take thee for a child with such a beard on thy face? Is there not diggon for that, too, cousin?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: I must not go; lend me your ear awhile,
I’ll give you reasons to the contrary.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: Sure this is an endless piece of work the king has sent us about!

speech.speaker: 2. GENT.
speech.line: Kings may do it, man, the like has been done to find out the unicorn.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: Which will be sooner found, I think, than this fiend-begotten child we seek for.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT.
speech.line: Pox of those conjurers that would speak of such a one, and yet all their cunning could not tell us where to find him.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: In Wales they said assuredly he lives; come, let’s enquire further.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Uncle, your persuasions must not prevail with me; I know mine enemies better than you do.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I say thou art a bastard, then, if thou disobey thine uncle. Was not Joan Go-to-’t, thy mother, my sister? If the devil were thy father, what kin art thou to any man alive but bailies and brokers? And they are but brothers-in-law to thee neither.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: How’s this? I think we shall speed here.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT.
speech.line: Ay, and unlooked for, too; go near and listen to them.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Hast thou a beard to hide it? Wilt thou show thyself a child? Wilt thou have more hair than wit? Wilt thou deny thy mother, because nobody knows thy father? Or shall thine uncle be an ass?

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: Bless ye, friend, pray what call you this small gentleman’s name?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Small, sir! A small man may be a great gentleman, his father may be of an ancient house for aught we know, sir.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT.
speech.line: Why, do you not know his father?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: No, nor you neither, I think, unless the devil be in ye.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: What is his name, sir?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: His name is my cousin, his education is my sister’s son, but his manners are his own.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Why ask ye, gentlemen? My name is Merlin.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Yes, and a goshawk was his father for aught we know, for I am sure his mother was a windsucker.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT.
speech.line: He has a mother, then?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: As sure as I have a sister, sir.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: But his father you leave doubtful?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Well, sir, as wise men as you doubt whether he had a father or no.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: Sure this is he we seek for.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT.
speech.line: I think no less, and, sir, we let you know the king hath sent for you.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: The more child he, and he had been ruled by me, he should have gone before he was sent for.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: May we not see his mother?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Yes, and feel her, too—if you anger her. A devilish thing, I can tell you, she has been. I’ll go fetch her to ye.

speech.speaker: 2. GENT.
speech.line: Sir, it were fit you did resolve for speed. You must unto the king.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: My service, sir, shall need no strict command. It shall obey most peaceably, but needless ’tis to fetch what is brought home. My journey may be stayed. The king is coming hither with the same quest you bore before him! Hark! This drum will tell ye.

stagedir.dir: Drums within beat a slow march.

speech.speaker: 1. GENT.
speech.line: This is some cunning, indeed, sir.

stagedir.dir: Flourish. Enter Vortiger reading a letter; Proximus, with drum, and Soldiers, &c.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: Still in our eye your message, Proximus, we keep to spur our speed. Ostorius and Octa we shall salute with succor against Prince Uther and Aurelius, whom now we hear encamps at Winchester. There’s nothing interrupts our way so much as doth the erection of this famous castle; that, spite of all our art and daily labor, the night still ruins.

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: As erst I did affirm, still I maintain, the fiend-be-gotten child must be found out, whose blood gives strength to the foundation. It cannot stand else.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: Ha! Is ’t so? Then, Proximus, by this intelligence he should be found. Speak! Is this he you tell of?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Yes, sir; and I his uncle, and she his mother.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: And who is his father?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Why, she, his mother, can best tell you that; and yet I think the child be wise enough, for he has found his father.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: Woman, is this thy son?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: It is, my lord.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: What was his father, or where lives he?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Mother, speak freely and unastonished;
That which you dared to act, dread not to name.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: In which I shall betray my sin and shame.

But, since it must be so, then know, great king, all that myself yet knows of him, is this: In pride of blood and beauty I did live; my glass the altar was, my face the idol. Such was my peevish love unto myself, that I did hate all other; such disdain was in my scornful eye, that I supposed no mortal creature worthy to enjoy me; thus, with the peacock, I beheld my train, but never saw the blackness of my feet. Oft have I chid the winds for breathing on me, and cursed the sun, fearing to blast my beauty. In midst of this most leprous disease, a seeming fair young man appeared unto me, in all things suiting my aspiring pride, and with him brought along a conquering power, to which my frailty yielded, from whose embraces this issue came. What more he is, I know not.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: Some Incubus, or spirit of the night, begot him, then; for sure no mortal did it.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: No matter who, my lord: leave further quest, since ’tis as hurtful as unnecessary more to enquire. Go to the cause, my lord, why you have sought me thus.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: I doubt not but thou knowest; yet, to be plain, I sought thee for thy blood.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: By whose direction?

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: By mine! My art infallible instructed me, upon thy blood must the foundation rise of the king’s building; it cannot stand else.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Hast thou such leisure to enquire my fate, and let thine own hang careless over thee? Know’st thou what pendulous mischief roofs thy head—how fatal, and how sudden?

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: Pish, bearded abortive! Thou foretell my danger! My lord, he trifles to delay his own.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: No, I yield myself; and here, before the king, make good thine augury, as I shall mine. If thy fate fall not, thou hast spoke all truth, and let my blood satisfy the king’s desires. If thou thyself wilt write thine epitaph, despatch it quickly; there’s not a minute’s space ’twixt thee and death.

speech.speaker: PROX.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha!

stagedir.dir: A stone falls and kills Proximus.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Ay, so thou mayst die laughing.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: Ha! This is above admiration. Look! Is he dead?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Yes, sir. Here’s brains to make mortar on, if you’ll use them. Cousin Merlin, there’s no more of this stone fruit ready to fall, is there? I pray give your uncle a little fair warning.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Remove that shape of death. And now, my lord, for clear satisfaction of your doubts, Merlin will show the fatal cause that keeps your castle down, and hinders your proceedings. Stand there, and, by an apparition, see the labor and end of all your destiny. Mother and uncle, you must be absent.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Is your father coming, cousin?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Nay, you must begone.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Come, you’ll offend him, brother.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I would fain see my brother-in-law: if you were married, I might lawfully call him so.

stagedir.dir: Merlin strikes his wand. Thunder and lightning. Two dragons appear, a white and a red. They fight awhile and pause.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Be not amazed, my lord, for on the victory
Of loss or gain, as these two champions ends,
Your fate, your life and kingdom, all depends;
Therefore, observe it well.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: I shall: heaven be auspicious to us.

stagedir.dir: Thunder. The two dragons fight again, and the white dragon drives off the red.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: The conquest is on the white dragon’s part: now, Merlin, faithfully expound the meaning.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Your grace must, then, not be offended with me.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: It is the weakest part I have found in thee to doubt of me so slightly. Shall I blame my prophet that foretells me of my dangers? Thy cunning I approve most excellent.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Then know, my lord, there is a dampish cave, the nightly habitation of these dragons, vaulted beneath where you would build your castle, whose enmity and nightly combats there maintain a constant ruin of your labor. To make it more plain—the dragons, then, yourself betoken, and the Saxon king; the vanquished red, is, sir, your dreadful emblem.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: Oh, my fate!

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Nay, you must hear with patience, royal sir. You slew the lawful king, Constantius: ’t was a red deed; your crown his blood did cement. The English Saxon, first brought in by you for aid against Constantius’ brethren, is the white horror, who, now knit together, have driven and shut you up in these wild mountains; and though they now seek to unite with friendship, it is to wound your bosom, not embrace it; and, with an utter extirpation, drive the Britons out and plant the English. Seek for your safety, sir, and spend no time to build the airy castles; for prince Uther, armed with vengeance for his brother’s blood, is hard upon you. If you mistrust me, and to my words crave witness, sir, then know here comes a messenger to tell you so.

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: My lord, prince Uther!

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: And who else, sir?

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: Edol, the great general.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: The great devil! They are coming to meet us?

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: With a full power, my lord.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: With a full vengeance they mean to meet us; so we are ready to their confront as full march double footing. We’ll lose no ground, nor shall their numbers fright us.
If it be fate, it cannot be withstood;
We got our crown so, be it lost in blood.

stagedir.dir: Enter Prince Uther, Edol, Cador, Earl of Cornwall, Edwin, and Toclio, with drums and soldiers.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Stay and advise. Hold, drum!

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Beat, slave! Why do you pause?—why make a stand? Where are our enemies? Or do you mean we fight amongst ourselves?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Nay, noble Edol, let us here take counsel. It cannot hurt. It is the surest garrison to safety.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Fie, on such slow delays! So fearful men, that are to pass over a flowing river, stand on the bank to parley of the danger till the tide rise, and they be swallowed. Is not the king in field?

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Proud Vortiger, the traitor, is in field.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: The murderer and usurper.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Let him be the devil, so I may fight with him. For heaven’s love, sir, march on. Oh, my patience! Will you delay until the Saxons come to aid his party!

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: There’s no such fear; prithee be calm awhile. Hark, it seems by this, he comes or sends to us.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: If it be for parley, I will drown the summons. If all our drums and hoarseness, choke me not.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Nay, prithee hear. From whence art thou?

speech.speaker: 1. WEL. CAPT.
speech.line: From the king Vortiger.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Traitor, there’s none such. Alarum drum, strike slave, or by mine honor I will break thy head, and beat thy drum’s heads both about thine ears.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Hold, noble Edol. Let’s hear what articles he can enforce.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: What articles, or what conditions can you expect to value half your wrong, unless he kill himself by thousand tortures, and send his carcase to appease your vengeance for the foul murder of Constantius, and that’s not a tenth part neither.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: ’Tis true, my brother’s blood is crying to me now. I do applaud your counsel. Hence, begone!
We’ll hear no parley now but by our swords.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: And those shall speak home in death-killing words. Alarum to the fight! Sound, sound the alarum!

stagedir.dir: Alarum. Enter Edol’s forces, driving Vortiger’s force before him. Then enter Prince Uther, pursuing Vortiger.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: Dost follow me?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Yes, to the death I will.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: Stay, be advised. I would not be the only fall of princes. I slew thy brother.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Thou didst, black traitor; and in that vengeance, I pursue thee.

speech.speaker: VORT.
speech.line: Take mercy for thyself, and flee my sword. Save thine own life as satisfaction, which here I give thee for thy brother’s death.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Give what’s thine own—a traitor’s heart and head; that’s all thou art right lord of: the kingdom which thou usurp’st, thou most unhappy tyrant, is leaving thee; the Saxons which thou brought’st to back thy usurpations are grown great, and where they seat themselves, do hourly seek to blot the records of old Brute and Britons from memory of men, calling themselves Hengist-men and Hengist-land, that no more the Briton name be known; all this by thee, thou base destroyer of thy native country.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: What, are you talking?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Hold, Edol!

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Hold out, my sword, and listen not to king
Or prince’s word.
There’s work enough abroad; this task is mine.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Prosper thy valor as thy virtues shine.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the field of battle.

stagedir.dir: Enter Cador, Earl of Cornwall and Edwin.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Bright Victory herself fights on our part; and, buckled in a golden beaver, rides triumphantly before us.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Justice is with her, whoever takes the true and rightful cause; let us not lag behind them.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Here comes the prince. How goes our fortunes, sir?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Hopeful and fair, brave Cador; proud Vortiger, beat down by Edol’s sword, was rescued by the following multitudes; and now for safety’s fled unto a castle here standing on the hill; but I have sent a cry of hounds as violent as hunger, to break his strong walls, or if they fail,
We’ll send in wildfire to dislodge him thence,
Or burn them all with all-flaming violence.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the field of battle.

stagedir.dir: Flourish of Trumpets. Enter Prince Uther, Edol, Cador, Earl of Cornwall, Edwin, and Toclio, with Drum and Soldiers.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Look, Edol! Still this fiery exhalation shoots his his frightful horrors on the amazed world: see in the beam that’s ’bout his flaming ring, a dragon’s head appears, from out whose mouth two flaming snakes of fire stretch east and west.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: And see, from forth the body of the star, seven smaller blazing streams, directly point on this affrighted kingdom.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: ’Tis a dreadful meteor.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: And doth portend strange fears.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: This is no crown of peace; this angry fire hath something more to burn than Vortiger: if it alone were pointed at his fall, it would pull in his blasing pyramids and be appeased, for Vortiger is dead.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: These never come without their large effects.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: The will of heaven be done; our sorrow’s this; We want a mystic Python to expound this fiery oracle.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Oh no, my lord; you have the best that ever Britain bred; and durst I prophesy of your prophet, sir, none like him shall succeed him.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: You mean Merlin.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: True, sir; wondrous Merlin: he met us in the way, and did foretel the fortunes of this day successful to us.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: He’s sure about the camp; send for him, sir.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: He told the bloody Vortiger his fate, and truly, too; and if I could give faith to any wizard’s skill, it should be Merlin.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: And see, my lord; as if to satisfy your highness’ pleasure, Merlin is come.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: See, the comet’s in his eye; disturb him not.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: With what a piercing judgment he beholds it!

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Whither will heav’n and fate translate this kingdom!
What revolutions, rise and fall of nations,
Is figured yonder in that star, that sings
The change of Britain’s fate and death of kings?
Ha! He’s dead already; how swiftly mischief creeps!
Thy fatal end, sweet prince, e’en Merlin weeps.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: He does foresee some evil; his action shows it; for ere he does expound, he weeps the story.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: There’s another weeps, too. Sirrah, dost thou understand what thou lamentest for?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: No, sir. I am his uncle, and weep because my cousin weeps. Flesh and blood cannot forbear.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Gentle Merlin, speak thy prophetic knowledge in explanation of this fiery horror, from which we gather from thy mournful tears much sorrow and disaster in it.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: ’Tis true, fair prince; but you must hear the rest with patience.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: I vow I will, though it portend my ruin.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: There’s no such fear. This brought the fiery fall of Vortiger, and yet not him alone. This day is fallen a king more good—the glory of our land—the mild and gentle, sweet Aurelius.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Our brother!

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Forefend it, heaven.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: He at his palace royal, at Winchester, this day is dead and poisoned.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: By whom? Or by what means, Merlin?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: By the traitorous Saxons.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: I ever feared as much. That devil, Ostorius, and the damned witch, Artesia, sure have done it.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Poisoned! Oh look further, gentle Merlin. Behold the star again, and do but find revenge for me, though it cost thousand lives, and mine the foremost.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Comfort yourself; the heavens have given it fully. All the portentous ills to you are told: now hear a happy story, sir, from me to you and to your fair posterity.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Methinks I see something like a peeled onion; it makes me weep again.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Be silent, uncle; you’ll be forced else.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Can you not find in the star, cousin, whether I can hold my tongue or no?

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Yes, I must cut it out.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Phew! You speak without book, sir. My cousin Merlin knows.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: True, I must tie it up. Now speak your pleasure, uncle.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Hum—hum—hum—hum.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: So, so! Now observe, my lord, and there behold above yon flame-haired beam that upward shoots, appears a dragon’s head, out of whose mouth two streaming lights point their flame-feathered darts contrary ways, yet both shall have their aims. Again behold from the ignisirent body seven splendent and illustrious rays are spread, all speaking heralds to this Britain isle, and thus they are expounded. The dragon’s head is the hieroglyphic that figures out your princely self, that here must reign a king; those bi-formed fires that from the dragon’s mouth shoot east and west, emblem two royal babes which shall proceed from you, a son and daughter; her pointed constellation north-west bending,
Crowns her a queen in Ireland, of whom first springs
That kingdom’s title to the Britain kings.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Hum, hum, hum.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: But of your son, thus fate and Merlin tells:
All aftertimes shall fill their chronicles
With fame of his renown, whose warlike sword
Shall pass through fertile France and Germany,
Nor shall his conquering foot be forced to stand,
Till Rome’s imperial wreath hath crowned his fame
With monarch of the west, from whose seven hills,
With conquest, and contributary kings,
He back returns t’enlarge the Britain bounds,
His heraldry adorned with thirteen crowns.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Hum, hum, hum.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: He to the world shall add another worthy, and as a loadstone for his prowess, draw a train of martial lovers to his court. It shall be then the best of knighthood’s honor at Winchester to fill his castle hall, and at his royal table sit and feast—
In warlike orders, all their arms round hurled,
As if they meant to circumscribe the world.

stagedir.dir: He touches the Clown’S mouth with his wand.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Hum, hum, hum. Oh that I could speak a little!

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: I know your mind, uncle, again be silent.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Thou speak’st of wonders, Merlin; prithee go on, declare at full this constellation.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Those seven beams pointing downwards, sir, betoken the troubles of this land, which then shall meet with other fate. War and dissension strive to make division till seven kings agree to draw this kingdom to a heptarchy.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Thine art hath made such proof that we believe thy words authentical; be ever near us, my prophet, and the guide of all my actions.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: My service shall be faithful to your person, and all my studies for my country’s safety.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Hum, hum, hum.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Come, you are released, sir.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Cousin, pray help me to my tongue again: you do not mean I shall be dumb still, I hope.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Why, hast thou not thy tongue?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Ha! Yes, I feel it now; I was so long dumb I could not tell whether I spoke or no.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Is it thy advice we presently pursue the bloody Saxons, that have slain my brother?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: With your best speed, my lord; prosperity will keep you company.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: Take then your title with you, royal prince, ’t will add unto our strength; long live king Uther.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Put the addition to it that heaven hath given you. The dragon is your emblem, bear it bravely, and so live long and ever happy, styled Uther-Pendragon, lawful king of Britain.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Thanks, Edol, we embrace the name and title; and in on shield and standard shall the figure of a red dragon still be borne before us to fright the bloody Saxons. Oh, my Aurelius, sweet rest thy soul! Let thy disturbed spirit
Expect revenge, think what it would, it hath,
The dragon’s coming in his fiery wrath.

scene.scenelocation: A barren waste, a huge rock appearing.

stagedir.dir: Thunder, then music. Enter Joan, fearfully, the Devil following her.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Hence, thou black horror, is thy lustful fire kindled again? Not thy loud-throated thunder, nor thy adulterous infernal music, shall e’er bewitch me more; oh, too, too much, is passed already.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: Why dost thou fly me? I come a lover to thee, to embrace, and gently twine thy body in mine arms.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Out, hell-hound.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: What hound soe’er I be,
Fawning and sporting as I would with thee,
Why should not I be stroked and played withal?
Wilt thou not thank the lion might devour thee,
If he shall let thee pass?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Yes, thou art he; free me, and I’ll thank thee.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: Why, whither wouldst? I am at home with thee, thou art mine own; have we not charge of family together? Where is your son?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Oh, darkness, cover me.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: There is a pride which thou hast won by me, the mother of a fame shall never die. Kings shall have need of written chronicles to keep their names alive, but Merlin none; ages to ages shall, like Sabalists,
Report the wonders of his name and glory,
While there are tongues and times to tell his story.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Oh, rot my memory before my flesh; let him be called some hell-or earth-bred monster, that ne’er had hapless woman for his mother. Sweet death deliver me—hence from my sight—why shouldst thou now appear? I had no pride nor lustful thought about me to conjure and call thee to my ruin, whenas at first thy cursed person became visible.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: I am the same I was.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: But I am changed.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: Again I’ll change thee to the same thou wert, quench to my lust; come forth, by thunder led, my coadjutors in the spoil of mortals.

Clasp in your ebon arms that prize of mine; mount her as high as palled Hecate, and on this rock I’ll stand to cast up fumes and darkness o’er the blue-faced firmament; from Britain, and from Merlin I’ll remove her; they ne’er shall meet again.

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Help me, some saving hand, if not too late; I cry let mercy come.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Stay you black slaves of night! Let loose your hold! Set her down safe, or by the infernal Styx, I’ll bind you up with exorcisms so strong, that all the black pentagaron of hell shall ne’er release you. Save yourselves and vanish.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: Ha! What’s he?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: The child has found his father! Do you not know me?

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: Merlin!

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Oh, help me, gentle son.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Fear not, they shall not hurt you.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: Relievest thou her to disobey thy father?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Obedience is no lesson in your school; nature and kind to her commands my duty; the part that you begot was against kind, so all I owe to you is to be unkind.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: I’ll blast thee, slave, to death, and on this rock stick thee an eternal monument.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Ha, ha! Thy power’s too weak; what art thou, devil, but an inferior lustful Incubus, taking advantage of the wanton flesh, wherewith thou dost beguile the ignorant? Put off the form of thy humanity, and crawl upon thy speckled belly, serpent, or I’ll unclasp the jaws of Acheron, and fix thee ever in the local fire.

speech.speaker: DEV.
speech.line: Traitor, to hell! Curse that I e’er begot thee.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Thou didst beget thy scourge; storm not nor stir, the power of Merlin’s art is all confirmed in the Fate’s decretals. I’ll ransack hell, and make thy master bow unto my spells; thou first shall taste it.

stagedir.dir: Thunder and lightning in the rock.

line.foreign: Tenebrarum precis, divitiarum, et inferorum, Deus, hunc Incubum in ignis eterni abiscum, accipite aut in hoc carcére tenebroso, in sempiternum astringere mando.

speech.line: So there beget earthquakes, or some noisome damps, for never shall thou touch a woman more. How cheer you, mother?

speech.speaker: JOAN.
speech.line: Oh, now my son is my deliverer, yet I must name him with my deepest sorrow.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Take comfort now, past times are ne’er recalled; I did foresee your mischief and prevent it. Hark, how the sounds of war now call me hence to aid Pendragon, that in battle stands against the Saxons, from whose aid Merlin must not be absent. Leave this soil, and I’ll conduct you to a place retired, which I by art have raised, called Merlin’s Bower; there shall you dwell with solitary sighs, with groans and passions your companions, to weep away this flesh you have offended with, and leave all bare unto your aerial soul; and when you die, I will erect a monument upon the verdant plains of Salisbury; no king shall have so high a sepulcher, with pendulous stones that I will hang by art, where neither lime nor mortar shall be used, a dark enigma to thy memory, for none shall have the power to number them, a place that I will hallow for your rest,
Where no night-hag shall walk, nor ware-wolf tread,
Where Merlin’s mother shall be sepulcherd.

stagedir.dir: Enter Lord Donobert, Earl of Gloucester, and Hermit.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Sincerely, Gloster, I have told you all. My daughters are both vowed to single life, and this day gone into the nunnery, though I begot them to another end, and fairly promised them in marriage,—one to earl Cador; t’other to your son, my worthy friend, the earl of Gloster. Those lost, I’m lost: they are lost, all’s lost. Answer me this, then,—is ’t a sin to marry?

speech.speaker: HER.
speech.line: Oh, no, my lord!

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Go to, then, I’ll go no further with you. I persuade you to no ill: persuade you, then, that I persuade you well.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: ’T will be a good office in you, sir.

stagedir.dir: Enter Cador, Earl of Cornwall and Edwin.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Which, since they thus neglect, my memory shall lose them now for ever. See, see! The noble lords, their promised husbands! Had fate so pleased, you might have called me father.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Those hopes are past, my lord, for ever: this minute we saw them both enter the monastery, secluded from the world and men for ever.

speech.speaker: CAD.
speech.line: ’Tis both our griefs we cannot, sir; but, from the king, take you the time’s joy from us. The Saxon king, Ostorius, slain, and Octa fled; that woman-fury, queen Artesia, is fast in hold, and forced to re-deliver London and Winchester (which she had fortified) to princely Uther, lately styled Pendragon, who now triumphantly is marching hither to be invested with the British crown.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: The joy of this shall banish from my breast all thought that I was father to two children, two stubborn daughters, that have left me thus. Let my old arms embrace and call you sons; for by the honor of my father’s house I’ll part my estate most equally betwixt you.

speaker.long: Edwin and Cador, Earl of Cornwall

speech.speaker: EDW. AND CAD.
speech.line: Sir, you are most noble.

stagedir.dir: Flourish of trumpets. Enter Edol, with Drum and Colors; Oswald, bearing the Standard; Toclio, the Shield, with the Red Dragon pictured on them; two Bishops, with the Crown; Prince Uther, Merlin, Artesia, bound, Guards, and Clown.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Set up our shield and standard, noble soldiers:
We have fair hope that though our dragon sleep,
Merlin will us and our fair kingdom keep.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: As his uncle lives I warrant you.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Happy restorer of the Briton’s fame: up-rising sun, let us salute thy glory! Ride in a day perpetual about us, and no night be in thy throne’s zodiac! Why do we stay to bind those princely brows with this imperial honor?

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Stay, noble Gloster; that monster first must be expelled our eye, or else we take no joy in it.

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: If that be hindrance, give her quick judgment, and send her hence to death; she has long deserved it.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Let my sentence stand for all: take her hence, and stake her carcase in the burning sun till it be parched and dry; and then flay off her wicked skin, and stuff the pelt with straw, to be shown up and down at fairs and markets. Twopence a-piece to see so foul a monster will be a fair monopoly.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha!

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Dost laugh, Erictho?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Yes, at thy poor invention; is there no better torture-monger?

speech.speaker: DONO.
speech.line: Burn her to dust.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: That’s a phœnix-death, and glorious.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Ay, that’s too good for her.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Alive she shall be buried, circled in a wall, thou murderess of a king; there starved to death.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Then I’ll starve death when he comes for his prey; and i’ the meantime I’ll live upon your curses.

speech.speaker: EDOL.
speech.line: Ay, ’tis diet good enough; away with her.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: With joy, my best of wishes is before;
Thy brother’s poisoned, but I wanted more.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Why does our prophet, Merlin, stand apart, sadly observing these our ceremonies, and not applaud our joys with thy hid knowledge? Let thy divining art now satisfy some part of my desires. For well I know ’tis in thy power to show the full event that shall both end our reign and chronicle. Speak, learned Merlin, and resolve my fears; whether by war we shall expel the Saxons, or govern what we hold with beauteous peace in Wales and Britain?

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: Long happiness attend Pendragon’s reign; what heaven decrees, fate has no power to alter. The Saxons, sir, will keep the ground they have, and by supplying numbers still increase till Britain be no more. So please your grace I will, in visible apparitions, present you prophecies which shall concern—
Succeeding princes, which my art shall raise,
Till men shall call these times the latter days.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Do it, my Merlin, and crown me with much joy and wonder.

stagedir.dir: Hautboys. Enter King Arthur in armor, his shield quartered with thirteen crowns. At the other door enter divers princes who present their crowns to him at his feet, and do him homage. Then enters Death and strikes him. He, growing sick, crowns Constantine.

speech.speaker: MERL.
speech.line: This king, my lord, presents your royal son, who, in his prime of years, shall be so fortunate, that thirteen several princes shall present their several crowns to him, and all kings else shall so admire his fame and victories, that they shall all be glad, either through fear or love, to do him homage; but death (who favors neither the weak nor valiant) in the midst of all his glories, soon shall seize him, scarcely permitting him to appoint one in all his purchased kingdoms to succeed him.

speech.speaker: UTH.
speech.line: Thanks to our prophet for this so wished-for satisfaction, and hereby now we learn that always fate must be observed whatever that decree,
All future times shall still record this story,
Of Merlin’s learnèd worth, and Arthur’s glory.
